COLIT-UA  110 Tragedy 
Historical and critical study of the idea and practice of tragedy from Greek times to the present.

COLIT-UA  111 Comedy 
Historical and critical study of comic forms, themes, and traditions in a number of Western cultures from Aristophanes and earlier classical writing to absurdist and postmodern notions of comic forms. Provides an opportunity to study the 20th-century mingling of tragedy and comedy into the tragicomedy. The aim is to evolve a critical perspective on comedy for our time. Complements Department of Classics offerings in Greek and Roman comedy.

COLIT-UA  115 Modernist Fiction: 
Focuses on both formal and thematic aspects of important innovative works of fiction from approximately the first half of the 20th century in Western Europe, the United States, and Latin America. Authors include Joyce, Woolf, Gide, Sartre, Mann, Faulkner, Carpentier, S?bato, and Rulfo.

COLIT-UA  137

   Literatures,Tricksters & Cultural Exchange

The history and functioning of the trickster figure in texts and oral tales of various cultures. The trickster?s presentation of a tension between different norms of rationality. Relations of languages, reasons, and hegemonies. Cultural crossovers, usings, and borrowings. COLIT-UA  425

   Classics in Middle Ages & The Renaissance

The early modern period is frequently characterized as marking a moment of "epistemic rupture," a transition of dramatic proportions during which the grounds of what constituted certain knowledge changed. Several fundamental questions emerge as a consequence: how do we know something is true? When is it legitimate to question our beliefs about cherished values, morals, and assumptions about the order of the world? How does the intuition of radical uncertainty create new ethical dilemmas? And most central to our concerns: how do we describe the new literature that emerges to assuage the anxieti...

      more description for COLIT-UA  425 »

      



The early modern period is frequently characterized as marking a moment of "epistemic rupture," a transition of dramatic proportions during which the grounds of what constituted certain knowledge changed. Several fundamental questions emerge as a consequence: how do we know something is true? When is it legitimate to question our beliefs about cherished values, morals, and assumptions about the order of the world? How does the intuition of radical uncertainty create new ethical dilemmas? And most central to our concerns: how do we describe the new literature that emerges to assuage the anxieties of doubt? This course traces and interrogates these questions by examining the intersections between Renaissance literature and the history of skepticism (broadly defined) - that is, the phenomenon of questioning our knowledge in many, if not all, domains in which we ordinarily think knowledge is possible. We will cast a wide net, ranging from cosmographies and travel accounts of New World discoveries, to the discovery of new planets and new scientific systems; from fictional utopias and imagined worlds to problems of philosophic truth and political action; and from Reformation and Counter-Reformation polemics to the new, hybrid interpretations of Genesis.

COLIT-UA  729 Traditional Drama China & Japan 
The course will compare a set of Chinese and Japanese pre-modern dramas,
mainly as literature but also as performance, by exploring the contrasts
and parallels of incident, character, plot design, and theme of the two
theatrical traditions. Attention will be given to the historical background
of each work and to the social conditions and customs that each reflects.
The cultural salience of each work is also considered. Where possible and
appropriate scenes or entire plays will be screened for the class or
assigned for viewing.
